abstract.text: A representation of a URL load request that you use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.

inlineContent.text: encapsulates two essential properties of a load request: the URL to load and the policies used to load it. In addition, for HTTP and HTTPS requests,
includes the HTTP method (
, and so on) and the HTTP headers. Finally, custom protocols can support custom properties as explained in
only represents information about the request. Use other classes, such as

for an introduction to these techniques.

The Swift overlay to the Foundation framework provides the

The URL Loading System handles various aspects of the HTTP protocol for you (HTTP 1.1 persistent connections, proxies, authentication, and so on). As part of this support, the URL Loading System takes responsibility for certain HTTP headers:

If you set a value for one of these reserved headers, the system may ignore the value you set, or overwrite it with its own value, or simply not send it. Moreover, the exact behavior may change over time. To avoid confusing problems like this, do not set these headers directly.
The URL Loading System sets the
header based on whether the request body has a known length:
If so, it uses the identity transfer encoding and sets the
header to that known length. You see this when you set the request body to a data object.
If not, it uses the chunked transfer encoding and omits the
header. You see this when you set the request body to a stream.
If you implement a custom URL protocol by subclassing
, and it needs protocol-specific properties, extend
with accessor methods for those custom properties. In your accessor methods, call
and
to associate property values with the request.

A representation of a URL load request that you use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
The request body as an input stream.
The request’s cache policy.
The URL being requested.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the request should continue transmitting data before receiving a response from an earlier transmission.
Returns the value of the specified HTTP header field.
Creates a URL request for a specified URL.
The request body.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the request is allowed to use the cellular radio (if present).
The HTTP request method.
The main document URL associated with the request.
Creates a URL request with the specified URL, cache policy, and timeout values.
A Boolean value indicating whether the
implements the
protocol.
The request’s timeout interval, in seconds.
The network service type of the request.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the default cookie handling will be used for this request.
A dictionary containing all of the HTTP header fields for a request.
A Boolean value that indicates whether connections may use the network when the user has specified Low Data Mode.
A Boolean value that indicates whether connections may use a network interface that the system considers expensive.
The entity that initiates the network request.
The entities that can make a network request.
The constants used to specify interaction with the cached responses.
Constants that specify how a request uses network resources.
An alias for this value type's equivalent reference type.
